body: We've reverted to `commons-vfs2` to 2.1 and it is still popping up from time to time.  We're going to move our custom iterators out of the VFS classpath and see what happens.

I noticed #776  while looking at this PR
A brief description of how the bug worked and what was done to fix it would help reviewers evaluate the change by giving some context.

[Rfile](https://accumulo.apache.org/docs/2.x/getting-started/design#rfile) data blocks contain a sequential list of key values.  These data blocks can be cached.  For cached data blocks that are frequently accessed Accumulo builds an index.  The index is associated with the cached block.  This bug was caused by a thread trying to update the index of a block that was evicted from the cache.  This scenario should not cause an exception.  This change should avoid the exception.

I saw this while working on #782 yesterday and I was actually working on a fix.

`fs.defaultFS` is only used for qualifying unqualified paths (paths without a filesystem specified). It is probably bad practice to rely on this mechanism when writing Hadoop client code (it's too dependent on whatever Hadoop configuration is on the class path, or whichever Hadoop `Configuration` object was used to create the `Path` object).

Instead of providing our own qualification mechanism (which I think we **should not** do), we should encourage users to qualify their paths with a Hadoop filesystem instead, when we receive it in our API. If they choose not to do so, and instead rely on the Hadoop behavior of automatically qualifying it with `fs.defaultFS`, then we should not override that behavior with our own. It is not our responsibility to override the natural behavior of the Hadoop client library we're using.
The benefits of this method are unclear to me, given the considerations users must make. How about we just remove the method?

I am cool with removing the method. Users can still create a new client for a new user from an existing client using the following code:

```
AccumuloClient client = Accumulo.newClient().from(oldClient.info()).as(principal, token).build();

```

The above code is more clear than the following that we are creating a new client:

```java
AccumuloClient client = oldClient.changeUser(principal, token);

Can `token()` be added to `AccumuloClientImpl` rather than `AccumuloClient` to satisfy the requirements for `ClientContext`? I'm not sure it should be on the public API... and if we really need it, we could always add it later.

I think the method should be `Accumulo.newClientProperties()` instead... just to be more explicit about the scope of the properties.

:+1: to everything else in the proposal.

Seems like the following could work without `add()`.  Each time `table()` is called it implies you are starting a new table.

```java
AccumuloInputFormat.configure().clientInfo(info)
    .table(name).auths(auths)
    .table(name2).auths(auths2).ranges(myRanges)
    .table(name3).auths(auths3).fetchColumns(cols).samplerConfiguration(conf)
    .store(job);
```

Updated with feedback from @ctubbsii:

* Remove `changeUser()` and `info()` from AccumuloClient
* Use `Properties` where `ClientInfo` is used
* Keep `ClientInfo` as internal class
* Add `properties()` to AccumuoClient
* Stop creating `ClientInfo` from `Accumulo.newClient()` builder and create a `Accumulo.newClientProperties()` builder.

| Current | New |
|---------|-----|
| ClientInfo info = client.info() | Properties props = client.properties() |
| client.changerUser(user, token) | Accumulo.newClient().from(oldClient.properties()).as(user, token).build() |
| ClientInfo info = Accumulo.newClient().to(instance, zoo).from(user, token).info() | Properties props = Accumulo.newClientProperties().to(instance, zoo).from(user, token).build() |

> Seems like the following could work without add(). Each time table() is called it implies you are starting a new table.

OK I like this one.

I am thinking of only fixing this in 2.0.  Was thinking of fixing by making the new tablet metadata abstraction layer handle the root tablet.

In JIRA, we typically set a version if somebody wanted intended it to be fixed for that version, and then we bumped only if we couldn't get to it by the time we were ready to release. For many other issues, more "wish list" type items, or items that weren't well defined, or any specific timeline affiliated with them, we never set a version at all. For some issues that were bumped frequently, we removed the version entirely.

So, it varied a lot. Either way works for me... I just don't want to keep bumping (relabeling) low priority items that we never end up getting to.
Fixing in 2.0 only seems reasonable to me. It doesn't seem to have been much of a nuisance up to this point.

Yeah this would be good.  I still think it is pretty clear to do this:

```java
AccumuloInputFormat.configure().clientProperties(props).table(name)
      .scanIsolation(true) // not available with batchScan()
      .offlineScan(booleanVar) // not available with batchScan()
      .store(job);
```

I am not sure if the old MR code should be deprecated for 2.0.  It might make sense to keep it for 2.0 and hold off on releasing the new MR API until 2.1.  This should give the new API time to mature.

@keith-turner This issue was closed, but not labeled as merged or labeled as fixed in a version. Was it abandoned or superseded by another issue or PR?

I've seen this copy-into-place to fix stuck Hadoop before. IIRC, it happened before 2.6 also. This seems like a Hadoop bug. Maybe we can add complexity to Accumulo to fix it, but I'd hope that the fix can be pushed upstream into Hadoop, so we don't set a precedent of Accumulo taking responsibility for bugs in libraries Accumulo uses at the cost of its own complexity and maintainability (especially since our community is relatively small).

I'm sympathetic to the need to have this fixed in production, and don't inherently have a problem with Accumulo doing more stuff to be fault-tolerant... I'm just worried slightly that the increasing complexity in Accumulo is not a scalable solution this category of problem. Without seeing the code needed to fix this, it's hard to say whether it would be complex or simple in this case.

Regardless, I definitely think this should be brought to the attention of Hadoop (or whatever Hadoop vendor you're using).
I'm not that familiar with the new options for Java 8 and later. I'd have to look into it. This doesn't need to be a blocker, though. It's definitely not on my priority list.

Ok, that is a fair point.  Since the LogCloser is actually pluggable, we can write separate one that will do what we need until we can get the appropriate hadoop bugs fixed/installed on our system.  This has been brought to the attention of Hadoop and I believe most of the bugs in this area have been fixed and are destined for later versions of hadoop.  Closing this ticket.

Your commit message should be something like `Fix #810 - Replace MiniAccumulo LogWriter's with ProcessBuilder.redirectOutput()` as you are working on GitHub issue #810.  The `ACCUMULO-810` format refers to Accumulo JIRA issues (e.g [ACCUMULO-810](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-810)).  While the Accumulo JIRA instance is still around, it is only kept for historical reasons.  New issues should be created using GitHub.

Ah, that makes sense. I wonder if you can convert the organization account back to a regular user if you wanted to? Doesn't matter to me, though. I was just curious. :smiley_cat:

Also, although you can comment on the GitHub thread by replying to the email notifications as you've been doing, it's not necessarily the best practice, since it adds a lot of extra noise to the thread, especially if you include the original notification message quoted in your reply. I would use that reply-to-post feature sparingly and instead click on the "view it on GitHub" link and reply on the page directly.

`Fix #nnn` is even shorter than `Fixes #nnn -`, useful for trying to have succinct subject lines in the commit log. See also https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ for solid advice on commit log messages.

For this one, I would have done something like:

```
Fix #810 Improve MiniAccumulo STDOUT capture

Use `ProcessBuilder.redirectOutput()` to capture STDOUT from MiniAccumulo processes,
rather than a custom `LogWriter` class.
```
Accumulo clients created from the ClientContext do not need to be closed.

> Accumulo clients created from the ClientContext do not need to be closed.

Eventually, it shouldn't be possible to create an AccumuloClientImpl from a context. The context should contain everything we need. It should go from API to context in only one direction, but not back to API again (this implies flattening ClientContext with AccumuloClientImpl). A lot of that is from the migration away from ConnectorImpl internally... and will take time to migrate.

Looking at the code I found a potential problem.  Each bulk import has a unique fate transaction id stored in zookeeper.  There is code that prevents RPCs related to the bulk import from running if the fate transaction id is deleted from ZK. Also there is code to wait for all active RPCs to finish.  So the bulk import FATE op will delete the id from ZK and then wait for all tservers to complete any RPCs that were active before it was deleted.

The bulk import FATE op makes RPCs to intermediate tserver that inspect files.  Once the intermediate tserver determines where a file goes then makes an RPC to tserver that should load the file.  The problem is that only the intermediate RPC is checking the if the transaction id is active.  Really the final RPC should be doing this check.

Below are some places in the code where this is all happening.

 * [CompleteBulkImport line 42](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/CompleteBulkImport.java#L42) deletes the transaction id from ZK
 * [CopyFailed line 75](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/tableOps/CopyFailed.java#L75) waits for active RPCs to complete
* [ClientServiceHandler line 345](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/client/ClientServiceHandler.java#L345) Runs the intermediate RPC to inspect files.  This RPC is run using TransactionWatcher.  TransactionWatcher will not run the RPC if the id does not exist in ZK.  If it does exist then increments a counter for the number of RPCs running for that transaction.
 * [TabletServer line 463](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.2/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/TabletServer.java#L463)  This the RPC that actually loads a file into a tablet.  This RPC is not run using TransactionWatcher and I think it should.

I think the intermediate RPC should stop using TransactionWatcher and the final RPC should start using TransactionWatcher.  I don't think there is a benefit to the intermediate one using it and it puts more load on ZK.

Also I have been working on IT that sends a load message to a tablet, compacts the tablet, and then sends another load message.  This IT shows that the current code that tracks loads prevents a load after compact.

I am thinking of implementing the following solution.

First, If inconsistent locality groups are configured, then log a warning.  The reason for this is that locality groups are spread over multiple properties.  So current code (that works) may create a briefly inconsistent/incorrect config.  I would not want to break this code.  The warning could let them know it would be better to set the props in a different order.

Second, read the locality group config at the start of the minor compaction.  If its bad then use no locality groups when creating the new in mem map and writing out the file AND log a warning.   This allows the tablet server to free memory.

I understand the inconvenience, but I'm not sure this is a problem for Accumulo to solve. The file names for logging are under the user's control in the log4j configuration files. The hostname and port combination, on the other hand, is Accumulo's own internal registration information, when the tservers do service advertisement in ZooKeeper. They are separate things.

Because Accumulo tserver processes are going to start emitting logs right away, it's not even possible for the service itself to know what its port number is going to be (if you are using the automatic port assignment) before the log is emitted. If you really want the log file names to reflect the port number, it would be best to configure static port numbers in each tserver's configuration file and in their respective log4j configuration files.

Removed the 1.9.3 label (I think labeling it is premature, at this point, since it's not clear when/whether it will be solved).

One way this could be addressed is that we could have a separate logger, which emits the tserver's configuration once fully initialized (similarly to how auditing goes to a separate logger), which includes the port number and other initialization details. Users could configure this logger to go to a separate file in their log4j configuration... so that it doesn't roll over and/or get lost, and should have enough information to help the user correlate the logs by file name.
